bibl.title: Letter from Philip Showalter Hench to George P. Berry, March 23, 1953

div1.p: Hench informs Berry that Maass was an experimental case of yellow fever, but that Ames did not have experimental yellow fever. Furthermore, it is not certain that he had yellow fever at all. Hench suggests that if Ames meets the criteria for a Walter Reed Society award, he would also favor honoring Hanberry, Kissinger, Moran, and Jernegan.

div1.head: Letter from Philip Showalter Hench to George P. Berry, March 23, 1953
div1.opener:
March 23, 1953
Dr. George Packer Berry, Dean
Harvard Medical School
25 Shattuck Street
Boston, Massachusetts
My dear Doctor Berry:
div1.p:
I am sorry for the delay in answering your letter of March 3. I do not know
much about the basis for theaawards given by the Walter Reed Society but it
seems to me that I read somewhere that it has to be someone who has experi-
mented on himself. Clara Maas would come under that heading. Strictly speaking,
Dr. Roger Ames would not. Although he exposed himself constantly to yellow
fever patients, both before and during the Reed experiments, he never parti-
cipated in the experiments himself, directly as a volunteer, that is.

This brings up an interesting controversy. Mrs. Ames is living and has tried
for some years to get his services recognized by Congress. There is no question
but that he rendered very special and able service to Walter Reed and perhaps
it was at least a little behond the call of duty, however it was more or less
in line of duty and he certainly did not qualify for the roll of honor.

During this discussion the question has arisen as to whether Doctor Ames himself
contracted yellow fever. On occasion it has been the desire of some of his
protagonists to indicate that he did develop yellow fever while he was taking
care of yellow fever victims but this matter is in dispute. General Truby
and General Kean, who were so close to the whole affair, insist that Doctor
Ames never had yellow fever despite the claims of Mrs. Ames and others. In-
cidentally, Mrs. Ames was considerably younger than Doctor Ames and they
were married I think some years after the Cuba episode so that she knows
nothing directly. A few years ago I found in one of the collections of clinical
notes, I believe in Reed's handwriting, some very brief notes suggesting that
Doctor Ames was having yellow fever. The notes do not settle the matter because
they are extremely brief and could be used to support either side of the argu-
ment. Apparently for at least two or three days he was a yellow fever suspect
but the fever chart, which I think I also have (I certainly have seen it) is
also unimpressive. In any event, whether or not Doctor Ames had yellow fever, it
was not experimental nor did it develop, as I recall it, while he was taking
care of the patients at Camp Lazear.

My uncertainty in this matter is occasioned from the fact that I am dictating
this in my office from memory and my voluminous files on all these matters are
at home.

If Doctor Ames qualified otherwise, even though he was not a volunteer and did
not develop experimental yellow fever, I would certainly be in favor of honoring
him posthumously, but why not include the one lone surviving voluntter of the
experiments, James L. Hanberry, and for that matter, why not include posthumous

honors for Moran and Kissinger who were the first two volunteers; also Jernigan
who was so remarkable in that he took everything coming, the only man who did
this. As I recall it, Jernigan first took the fomites experiment. When that
horrible episode was finished, he was game to receive experimental yellow fever
which he did, and if my memory serves me, later to prove his immunity he took
another inoculation I think intravenously. On the score of willingness, there-
fore, he ranks at the top of the list with Moran and Kissinger who, in vol-
unteering first, started the ball rolling. There was one notable distinction
between Moran and Kissinger. Presumably both refused any money. Moran stuck
to his refusal. Kissinger weakened and let it be known that he was willing
to reconsider the matter so they gave him a watch and a cash gift of the
money, the two equaling what they would have given him as an ordinary
volunteer.
div1.closer: Sincerely, P. S. Hench, M.D. PSH:alc
